result.execSummary:
The defendant Lisa Ann Payne Hennen was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: lf extended supervision is revoked and the defendant will have a mandatory release from prison, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due.

Defendant shall provide a biological specimen for DNA analysis. Defendant has the right to request expungement of DNA analysis in writing through the Department of Justice.
Defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety.
Defendant to successfully complete Drug Treatment Court program.

timeConds.notes:
With Huber privileges consistent with the rules of the jail while the inmate maintains a minimum security status. The defendant, at the discretion of the Sheriff, may perform community service work as an inmate worker in the county jail and shall earn statutory good time for same. 
Condition time is stayed and may be imposed at the discretion of the drug treatment court judge.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Lisa Ann Payne Hennen

Disposition Form

Defendant Lisa Ann Payne Hennen appeared by video from Washington Co Jail, in custody. Attorney Tsz-King Tse in court for Lisa Ann Payne Hennen.  Prosecuting attorney Jeanette Kara Corbett in court for the State of Wisconsin. Case resolved; def to participate in DTC and will be transferred to Calm Harbor directly from the jail after this proceeding. Def waives preliminary hearing. Court accepts waiver and binds def over. State to file Information within 48 hrs. Def pleads guilty; is convicted and sentenced.
